title: Doomscrolling Learned Helplessness
context: People compulsively consume negative news on their phones — doomscrolling. The behavior feels like staying informed. In reality, it's a stress response that creates learned helplessness. Constant exposure to problems you can't solve — climate change, political dysfunction, global conflict — trains the brain that action is futile. The most informed people become the most paralyzed. They know everything that's wrong and feel powerless to change any of it.
hypothesis: Staying informed about world events helps people make better decisions and take meaningful action.

chain.root: Consume negative news continuously via social media and news apps

effects.label: Negativity bias in news creates distorted worldview
effects.impact: News is 90% negative despite most trends improving

children.label: People believe the world is getting worse when most metrics are improving
Catastrophizing becomes the default mental model
Good news doesn't generate clicks — negative selection bias in media

effects.label: Learned helplessness develops from exposure to unsolvable problems
effects.impact: Civic engagement and volunteering decline among heavy news consumers

children.label: Knowing about every global crisis creates paralysis, not action
Local problems (solvable) get less attention than global problems (unsolvable)
People substitute awareness for action — sharing an article feels like doing something

effects.label: Mental health deteriorates with consumption volume
effects.impact: Anxiety and depression correlate with news consumption hours

children.label: Cortisol levels elevated during and after doomscrolling sessions
Sleep disrupted by evening news consumption
Compulsive checking behavior mirrors addiction patterns

effects.label: Paradoxically, heavy consumers are less likely to act
effects.impact: Inverse correlation between news consumption and civic action

children.label: Emotional exhaustion from consuming leaves no energy for doing
Cynicism replaces optimism — 'nothing I do matters'

dontIf: You're already experiencing anxiety or depression symptoms
Your news consumption exceeds 1 hour per day without corresponding action
ifYouMust: Set a hard daily limit on news consumption — 30 minutes is enough to stay informed
Consume news at scheduled times, not on-demand — avoid the scroll
For every problem you read about, identify one local action you can take
Balance negative news with solutions journalism and progress reporting

alternatives.name: Weekly news digests
alternatives.note: Read a weekly summary instead of daily feeds — same information, 90% less anxiety

alternatives.name: Solutions journalism
alternatives.note: Follow outlets that cover what's working, not just what's broken

alternatives.name: Local focus
alternatives.note: Engage with local news and local action — where your effort actually makes a difference

falsifiability: Heavy news consumers show higher rates of civic engagement and volunteering than light consumers
Increased news consumption correlates with more accurate (not more negative) worldviews
Doomscrolling does not correlate with increased anxiety or depression in longitudinal studies

seo.description: Doomscrolling creates learned helplessness — heavy news consumers are 40% more anxious and paradoxically less likely to take civic action. Awareness substitutes for agency.
